description: Borrowed from Medieval Latin olibanum, Late Latin libanus, from Latin oleum libani (“oil of Lebanon”), from Ancient Greek λίβανος (líbanos, “frankincense (Boswellia carterii, now Boswellia sacra)”), from a Semitic source. See the Semitic root lbn لبن‎, meaning "white". Cognate with Biblical Hebrew לְבוֹנָה‎ (l'voná, “frankincense”), Arabic لبان‎ (lubān, “frankincense”). (Compare benzoin for a similar process of metanalysis.) Doublet of oliban.

entries.meaning: A gum resin from trees of the genus Boswellia, formerly used as a medicine and now mainly as incense. [from 14th c.]
